NATIONAL MERIT SEMIFINALISTS ANNOUNCED!
Liberty High School seniors Katie Baughman, Lily Baughman, Logan Parco, and Harrison Wheeler join Liberty North High School senior Rachel Kim as the LPS students named as National Merit Semifinalists. The National Merit Scholarship program is a highly competitive academic competition students qualify for by taking the PSAT/NMSQT test during their junior year. These talented high school seniors have an opportunity to continue in the competition to become National Merit Finalists, which include several requirements to advance to the Finalist level. Please join the LPS community in congratulating the hard work and dedication of these students as they continue on in the competition.

post_text: An important annual event that we host each year is Kindergarten Round-up, which is held for families of incoming kindergarten students. This event is traditionally held in face-to-face format in March, but due to the extended school closure, was postponed. We are now pleased to announce that this event will be held virtually for families the last week of May. This learning experience will incorporate social stories that capture all aspects of school life, where new kindergartners will meet the principal, as well as classroom teachers, and learn about the school environment through a virtual tour.

Liberty High School Seniors Caroline Wright and Carissa French have been selected to the Missouri Scholars 100 list. Missouri Scholars 100 is a statewide program honoring 100 of Missouri's top academic seniors. Selection is based primarily on a formula using the student's GPA and ACT/SAT scores, as well as meeting all the criteria of the Academic Decathlon.

Wright and French join Liberty North Seniors Delaney Clawson and Abigail Wagner, who were also recently announced to this prestigious list.

Since making the announcement of our school closure through the remainder of the school year earlier this afternoon, we have been inundated with questions from families. Examples of questions include: "Does this news affect summer school?", "When can we get our child's belongings from their school?", and "Will graduation events still take place?".

Please know that many of the questions you have may not yet have answers. Our entire LPS team will be working diligently in the coming days and weeks to develop the most effective plans, in an effort to best serve our students, families, and community. We will also be committed to providing you with regular updates addressing the numerous challenges that this extended closure has caused.

In the meantime, we will be regularly posting a series of "LPS Mailbag" posts here on our Facebook page that address many of the common questions we receive from families. Our first post is provided below.

Don't forget that we are #InThisTogetherLPS, and we will get through this TOGETHER.

post_text: We are proud to share the Missouri Scholars Academy participants for summer 2020. Missouri Scholars Academy is a three-week academic residential program for 330 of Missouri’s gifted students who are ready to begin their junior year in high school. The Academy is held each June on the campus of the University of Missouri, and administered by the University of Missouri Honors College. The Academy reflects Missouri’s desire to strive for excellence in education at all levels. The program is based on the premise that Missouri’s gifted youth must be provided with special opportunities for learning and personal development in order for them to realize their full potential. Congratulations on this great honor!

We appreciate so much the efforts of our custodial, maintenance, warehouse, and grounds staff members who work hard to provide our learners a great experience while at school.

At last night's Board meeting, we had the opportunity to recognize members of this group who banded together to pull off an incredible task to ensure that Franklin Elementary was able to open its doors on the first day following a significant building renovation that took place over the summer. Approximately 75 team members even gave up their final weekend before the school year started to come in and make sure the building was ready to go.

"Their positivity and can-do attitude throughout was amazing," said LPS Director of Facilities and Grounds Steve Aldrich. "In the end, they accomplished their goal."
